unnormalised: Okay, here is the generated text based on the specified parameters:
normalised: The bane of my existence, honestly, is scheduling meetings. Seriously. Half my workday goes in just trying to nail down a time that works for everyone. And in a team spread across Mumbai, Bangalore, and even London, it’s a proper headache. Finding that sweet spot is like trying to find a needle in a haystack made of Outlook invites.

unnormalised: The bane of my existence, honestly, is scheduling meetings. Seriously. Half my workday goes in just trying to nail down a time that works for everyone. And in a team spread across Mumbai, Bangalore, and even London, it’s a proper headache. Finding that sweet spot is like trying to find a needle in a haystack made of Outlook invites.
normalised: Just yesterday, I was trying to schedule a quick sync-up about the Q-three reports. Simple, right? Nope. First, Priya from Marketing is only free before eleven a.m. Then Rakesh in Sales can only do after three p.m. And don't even get me started on coordinating with our London office - adding another layer of time zone chaos to the mix. Suddenly, thirty minutes simple meeting has turned into a three-hour email thread.

unnormalised: Just yesterday, I was trying to schedule a quick sync-up about the Q3 reports. Simple, right? Nope. First, Priya from Marketing is only free before 11:00 AM. Then Rakesh in Sales can only do after 3 PM. And don't even get me started on coordinating with our London office - adding another layer of time zone chaos to the mix. Suddenly, 30 mins simple meeting has turned into a 3-hour email thread.
normalised: And the date! Oh, the date. I suggested fifteenth july two thousand and twenty four, and it turns out, for someone it's their kid's sports day. Then sixteenth July gets rejected as someone's on leave. Finally, we ended up with seventeenth july two thousand and twenty four at four p.m. I-S-T which honestly felt like a victory after all that negotiation. The P-M-s are no less. For the design review on second august twenty twenty four, Reena said she couldn't prep on first august because she has some family function that runs until twenty three fifty nine. So, there are more changes in schedule.

unnormalised: And the date! Oh, the date. I suggested 15/07/2024, and it turns out, for someone it's their kid's sports day. Then 16th July gets rejected as someone's on leave. Finally, we ended up with 17/07/2024 at 4:00 PM IST which honestly felt like a victory after all that negotiation. The PMs are no less. For the design review on 2/8/24, Reena said she couldn't prep on 1/8 because she has some family function that runs until 23:59. So, there are more changes in schedule.
normalised: The worst part is when people "prepone" or "postpone" at the last minute. I had a one-on-one with my manager scheduled for fourteen thirty yesterday. Ten minutes before, I get a message: "Can we push to sixteen hundred?" Like, seriously? I’ve already mentally blocked out that time, and now I have to rejig my entire afternoon. And what about the time I blocked out the cal for urgent work around zero nine hundred on twenty fifth december two thousand and twenty three? Got a message asking to postpone to sixteen hundred on the same day! Like I'm sitting around on Christmas for work.

unnormalised: The worst part is when people "prepone" or "postpone" at the last minute. I had a one-on-one with my manager scheduled for 14:30 yesterday. Ten minutes before, I get a message: "Can we push to 16:00?" Like, seriously? I’ve already mentally blocked out that time, and now I have to rejig my entire afternoon. And what about the time I blocked out the cal for urgent work around 09:00 on 25/12/2023? Got a message asking to postpone to 16:00 on the same day! Like I'm sitting around on Christmas for work.
normalised: And then there's the calendar invites themselves. How many times have I seen invites with just the date and a vague subject line like "Meeting"? No agenda, no attendees listed, no context whatsoever. I swear, sometimes I think people are just trying to mess with me. I once got a meeting invite just saying "urgent" at ten hundred. I had to message five people before I figured out what it was about. Turned out to be about ordering office chai!

unnormalised: And then there's the calendar invites themselves. How many times have I seen invites with just the date and a vague subject line like "Meeting"? No agenda, no attendees listed, no context whatsoever. I swear, sometimes I think people are just trying to mess with me. I once got a meeting invite just saying "urgent" at 10:00. I had to message five people before I figured out what it was about. Turned out to be about ordering office chai!
normalised: My coworker, Rohan, swears by some fancy scheduling tool that supposedly finds the best time for everyone automatically. He uses it to block time and then sends an invite that auto updates. I haven't tried it yet, but after this week, I might just cave. Anything to avoid the endless email chains and last-minute changes. Maybe I'll start blocking out random times in my calendar as "unavailable" just to make it even more difficult for everyone else. Okay, maybe not. But the thought is tempting.

normalised: Honestly, this whole process needs a complete overhaul. Maybe A-I can solve this someday. Imagine, an A-I assistant that understands everyone's schedules, priorities, and even their tolerance for early morning meetings. Until then, I'll just keep battling the calendar chaos, one poorly planned meeting at a time. Someone invent a time-turner, please?

unnormalised: Honestly, this whole process needs a complete overhaul. Maybe AI can solve this someday. Imagine, an AI assistant that understands everyone's schedules, priorities, and even their tolerance for early morning meetings. Until then, I'll just keep battling the calendar chaos, one poorly planned meeting at a time. Someone invent a time-turner, please?
normalised: I am gonna send a follow up mail. And I wanna make sure people read it. So, I'm gonna send it twice, once at fifteen hundred and again at fifteen fifteen. People have short memories.

unnormalised: I am gonna send a follow up mail. And I wanna make sure people read it. So, Imma send it twice, once at 15:00 and again at 15:15. People have short memories.
